abstract: Through more than a year of giant bailouts and bankruptcies, HSBC was one of the few big banks to emerge with its reputation largely intact, wrote Landon Thomas Jr. and Julie Werdigier of The New York Times. The global financial giant did bet on subprime mortgages – and lost. But it nonetheless managed to maintain a robust market value compared with its diminished peers, lending it an aura of unrivaled durability.
